<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Overall, The Best Place To Stay In NYC I stayed in the Affinia 50 from July 20th to July 25th 2005.We had a party of 8 so had two rooms on the 15th and 22nd floors. I've stayed here several times over the years both on business trips and with my family and children. Ownership has recently changed from the Manhattan East Suites to the Affinia Group. The hotel has also recently undergone a major upgrade and the rooms are now more plush and comfortable than previously. The hotel is excellent in almost every respect. The rooms are spacious (although there's a big variation in the sizes of rooms at the same price!). The bedrooms are outstanding. Huge comfortable beds with tasteful furnishings and even two dressing gowns. The location.... well it's unbeatable in the big apple. within walking distance of Midtown shopping, Broadway, Bloomies, and Grand Central Station. The only downside was the technology in the room. After the recent major refurbishment, I would have expected flat screen TVs instead of the antique monsters in the living room and bedrooms. I would also have expected free wireless internet acces instead of a $10 per day charge. Someone recently mentioned a 2-bedroom suite but I'm certain there are no 2-bed suites in the Affinia 50. Some lovely nearby restaurants and bars within a block also helped. All in all a great experience.  
<Date>Aug 31, 2005

<Author>baileybecker
<Content>Less than Perfect We stayed at the Affinia 50 this past weekend and were both slightly disappointed with our accomodations. When we booked on line with the Affinia website, we asked for a non smoking Studio Suite with two queen beds and the galley kitchen. We called two weeks in advance to ask for a non smoking room higher than the 5th floor. When we got to the hotel, we were given a king bed room with no kitchen, just a refrigerator on the 5th floor. They said that we could move the next day to another room, but that was too much of a hassle being gone all day and coming back to re pack your belongings and move, so we stayed in the king room. The air worked well in the room, but the noise level from the streets was tremendous, not to mention the fire alarm going off at 5 AM in the morning for 1/2 hour. Other than the hotel, New York was great and definately try and go to the Chelsea flea market and Ess-e-bagel down the street from the Affinia.

<Author>NYYankeeFan
<Content>Great place to stay I recently stayed at the Affinia 50 for my mom's birthday. The hotel is very clean and all the staff was friendly and accomodating. I called ahead of time to ask a question and mentioned that it was my mom's birthday, and they had a card and some candies waiting for us in our room, which I thought was a nice touch. There was a mixup with our original room (it had only one bed and not two, as we requested) but they fixed our problem right away and gave us a room with two queen beds and a kitchenette. The room was incredibily spacious (especially by Manhattan hotel standards) and the beds were the most comfortable I've ever slept on. The Club Room features newspapers, books, games and internet access, all for free. I really enjoyed my stay and will stay here again. My only complaints would be that there was no sponge in the kitchenette for cleaning dishes (the kitchen comes fully stocked with utensils, btw), our face towels weren't replaced when the room was cleaned, and it was a tad noisy - I heard someone sneeze when I was in the bathroom, could hear doors closing, etc. If you're not used to urban noises (sirens, buses, cars honking, etc.) you may find it tough to sleep - the street noise wasn't terrible, but I live in NYC, so I'm used to it! The location is great as it's easy to get anywhere else in the city without dealing with the huge crowds of people in Times Square, and you have the B49 bus right outside your door, the E, V and 6 trains down the block, and good food nearby, such as Ess-a-Bagel and Smith and Wollensky's. I highly recommend this hotel for your NYC visit.  
<Date>Aug 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Lived up to expectations! We stayed at the Affinia from the 27th to the 31st july 2005. We booked the hotel after reading the reviews on this site. I requested a quiet room (we live in the Shetland Islands and are NOT used to a lot of noise) and we were duly booked into a 1 bedroom suite on the 10th floor. We had a wonderful view and a very nice room. The maid service was excellent as was the staff on the front desk and the doorman (who managed to sort out our very late taxi to the airport). We enjoyed the wine and cheese and the children loved the fitness centre - we should have made more use of these facilities.There is an excellent deli around the corner called Esa bagel and within a couple of minutes walk a small supermarket. Having these on your doorstep made good use of the kitchen facilities in the room.We would recommend this hotel to anyone who wants to visit New York and wants to stay in an excellent location at a price that does not reflect the quality of the accomodation.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>50/50 rating for Affinia 50 My husband and I stayed at the Affinia 50 from July 26-30. We both had mixed feelings...super great location. Midtown is an ideal spot, central, bustling, safe, and fun. We requested a non-smoking room, but for some reason the entire floor seemed to be occupied by HEAVY smokers. We just bought a scented candle, since there were no other rooms available. The bed was indeed one of the comfiest ever, and the pillow menu was a fun diversion. Most of the reviews praised the staff for being extra nice and attentive. We did not have that expirience. The staff were professional, to be sure, but not warm, fuzzy, or exeptional in any way. All in all, the price was good, the room was clean, and we enjoyed our stay in the big apple, but next time we might shell out a bit more dough in hopes of having better service.

<Author>Sandcastles
<Content>Comfortable and convenient Our family (parents and two kids) stayed here for one night. I wish I'd arranged to stay there longer but I'd already booked and paid for three nights at the Holiday Inn on 57th - that was very, very ordinary by comparison. The desk and lobby staff at Affinia 50 were very welcoming. We just crashed there on the two king-sized beds - they were so comfortable. We didn't really use the kitchen but I can say that both the kitchen and the bathroom were a good size and of a reasonable standard. The kids loved the fact that Starbucks (still a novelty!) was just around the corner and we loved the food from Azure. This deli is just great. The hotel is close to 5th Ave and subways. E 50th St just felt a nicer area than W 57th where we spent the next 3 nights also. Incidentally we spent our very last night in NYC a week or so later in the Affinia across from Madison Sq Gardens - even better than Affinia 50 IMO!!!

<Author>kevinc
<Content>Too Good To Be True We selected Affinia 50 based on the outstanding reviews on this website. After our recent stay we realized these reviews were overrated and inaccurate and felt compelled to give a more realistic review. Also, the amenities indicated were exaggerated. Example, a galley kitchen with a refrigerator turned out to be a bar cooler with no kitchen in any way.While confirming our reservation we had requested a room on a higher floor and were told it would not be a problem. At check we were informed otherwise, that our reservation was only good for floors 1-5. After our obvious discontent the clerk supposedly upgraded us to a studio room on the 19th floor. We gladly offerd him a $ tip for doing so. While unpacking the room felt warm. We lowered the thermostat, upon returning to the room 5 hours later the room was still warm. We contacted the front desk, the maintenance man arrived and indicated he had repaired the problem. 2 hours later and the room was still warm, the a/c was not repaired! We reguested another room and was told the only available room was a regular roomon the 4th floor. It turns out this room was no different from our upgraded room except it had functioning a/c. The attitude of the staff was by no means hospitable, they were more like indifferent. We had to ask for fresh towels and soap? On our last night a notice was put under our room door indicating the entire floor would be without a/c or hot water the next day as major repairs were needed! We requested a 1pm checkout, was first told they could not do this as they were sold out. When asked how they could check people into rooms with no a/c or hot water the clerk repiled oh, okay you can have a late check out, with an attitude like she was doing us a favor! Thanks Affinia for a miserable stay! Be forewarned readers!  
<Date>Jul 27, 2005

<Content>A welcome home every time We stayed at the Affinia 50 from July 16 to 21st. I had booked through the hotel after they had agreed to match the Expedia rate. <Author>TheMildorks
<Content>Welcome home indeed After hours of deliberation over the many hotels available in New York City my boyfriend and I (well moreso I!) decided on the Affinia 50. After reading all of the extremely useful reviews on tripadvisor we took the plunge and managed to secure ourselves a great deal for the 4 nights we spent from July 16th to July 20th. Not only were we pleasantly surprised by the size of the room (which some people have mentioned previously as being small), but the overall decor and atmosphere of the boutique, club hotel was more than we both expected. The staff will greet you with welcome home on your arrival, the room is a cool haven from the opressive humidity outside; the bed is a cocoon which will soothe your tired muscles from all of the sightseeing and shopping which takes place in New York and the Aveda bathroom products will invigorate you to do it all over again! However most property decisions are made upon location and Affinia 50 is a winner. Close enough to walk into Times Square within 10 minutes, close to the beautiful Grand Central Station and very close to Saks and all of the Fifth Avenue stores. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone that wants to stay within their budget, have a brilliant and accesible location but most of all to feel like they have got more for their money. There is so much to see and do in NYC which means that the amount of time actually spent in your room is very little and spending more than necessary on a room you won't be in to me seems like a bad investment. The Affinia 50 is by no means a no frills place, for the money you pay I guarantee you will be more than impressed-we certainly were and can't wait to go again!  
<Date>Jul 22, 2005

<Author>Kelmag711
<Content>Nice Hotel at a Modest Price My family (wife and two daughters) stayed at the Affinia 50 for five nights in July, 2005. It is an outstanding hotel for the price. We had a one bedroom suite which included a nice sized separate bedroom with a very comfortable King bed, sitting area/living room with a fold out sofa bed and dinette, a small kitchen with a small range/oven, very small microwave, full-sized refrigerator and a dish-washer. The kitchen was equipped with plates/glasses/silverware for four. There are tons of shelves/closets/dressers for clothes and stuff. We requested a King bed, non-smoking, room on a high floor with a nice view. We got three out of the four - the view was a brick wall of the neighboring building. The front desk said they could get us a view room the next day for the remainder of our stay but we declined, once we had unpacked and settled in. One good thing about no view, it sure kept the street noise down - it was amazingly quiet for a mid-town Manhattan hotel. The rooms were nicely appointed with large TVs in the bedroom and sitting room. The bathroom was small and needed more shelf space (especially with a wife and two daughers!), but the shower was first rate. The kitchen was very small and the microwave was just large enough to handle microwave popcorn or a cup of hot water - but it was more than adequate for breakfast which was a lot easier and less expensive than having the family eat breakfast out every morning. The staff was friendly and helpful. There is a nice lounge on the second floor with a large screen TV, board games, coffee, newspapers and computers for internet access (there is also broadband access in the room). They have a wine and cheese happy hour Mon. - Thurs. that is free for guests. One of the best things about the Affinia 50 is its great location - on the corner of 50th and Third Avenue. It is one short block to the 50th and Lexington Ave. subway station which can take you just about anyplace in the city. In one day we traveled from the hotel to Ellis Island from the southern tip of Manhattan, the World Trade Center site, South Street seaport and my old neighborhood in the Northwest corner of the Bronx and back to the hotel for dinner at a nearby steak place - all on the subway using our 7 day fixed price/all you can ride pass (available at the Times Square Visitor Center on Bwy and 46th). It is also just a few blocks from Rockefeller Center (and the Today show!), Radio City Music Hall, Times Square/Theater District and dozens of first rate restaurants. Within a block of the hotel is a Smith and Wollensky Steak House, a very nice restaurant called La Magnette and another steal place - O'neil's. Also, there is a small grocery story around the corner and full-sized, 24 hr. Associated about four blocks away on Second Ave. Oh, there are two Starbucks within a block of the hotel. By booking several months ahead online and paying for the entire stay in advance, we got a rate of $229 per night ($189 for the first night). It would be hard to find another room (let alone a suite) in that area for under $400 per night. We were very pleased with the Affinia and look forward to returning in the future.  
<Date>Jul 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>We Didn't Want to Leave! When considering where to stay in New York (our first time visiting the city) we chose the Affinia 50 because of the praises and details we read at Trip Advisor. Because of the very detailed reviews, we knew just what to expect at the Affinia 50, and we weren't disappointed! We stayed in a Junior Suite and we were amazed at the size of the room. The room was huge and extremely comfortable, and we made good use of the full kitchen almost every day we were there. There is a lovely market with very reasonable prices just a couple of blocks away, so getting groceries was hassle-free. The bed was so nice, we're considering purchasing one from the website; and my husband is still raving about the pillow menu. The hotel is a distance from the theater district and other attractions, but the subway is just a couple of blocks away. We took the subway everywhere and never felt lost or unsafe. The staff at the Affinia 50 treated us like family. We felt extremely welcome and pampered during our stay! The second floor lounge is huge, with two big plasma screen TVs, games, comfy chairs, and breakfast or wine and cheese, depending on what time of day you are there. New York was amazing, and the Affinia 50 was by far the best hotel we've ever experienced! Thank you, Trip Advisor, for steering us in the direction of the Affinia 50.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Almost good We stayed at the Affinia 50 last night, in a studio suite with a king bed on the fourth floor. I had been expecting wonderful things based on the reviews here, but I'm sorry to say that our stay wasn't quite so pleasant.The hotel itself is quite nice, and the staff are all very friendly and helpful. Our problem with the hotel is that our room (408) was on the fourth floor and we could hear traffic noise pretty much all night. It didn't matter that the AC was on, when there's a New Yorker leaning on his horn at 2 a.m., you're going to hear it. I don't really fault the hotel for that, this is New York after all, and you have to expect some noise.The bed was very comfortable, as many of the reviewers have noted, but the pillows were not. We didn't get a chance to order from the pillow menu because we were too busy running around NYC. It was pretty much only until we got home at 11 pm (though perhaps we should have just called housekeeping then) that we tried the bed, and we were both too tired to want to have any hotel staff show up.That was really the first time we were in our room since checking in, and we began to notice a few problems. You really could hear the street noise from the 4th floor, even through the thick windows. Worse, you could hear the toilet flushing -- from next door and from above. There aren't cisterns on these toilets, so they employ some kind of high pressure flushing very similar in sound to those on airplanes. It was actually pretty scary the first time we flushed, and it was definitely scary when one of our neighbors flushed when we were trying to sleep.But the toilet sounds weren't the only problem with the plumbing. As I was brushing my teeth, I watched in awe as the sink slowly filled with dirty water, from the drain up. I could hear the sink and water running from upstairs, and figured there must be some problem with the drainage system. That would explain why, upon checking in, we found tiny flecks of various dark cruddy material lining the sink. At first, we thought they were decorative designs, but really, it was backwash. With toothbrush in hand, I stood and watching the horrid backflow slowly fill the sink. It didn't overflow, and eventually, it went back down, but I had to use the tub to do my brushing and flossing. (That's pretty gross, too, I admit.)When I made the reservation, I asked for a quiet room away from the elevators and stairs. And I was glad we did have a room far away, since the doors aren't very soundproofed and they tend to slam shut pretty loudly. There's an express elevator for the first to five floors, and on our floor, there was a room right next to that elevator. I felt bad for the people in that room, since they must have been subject to all kinds of inane early morning and late night hallway conversation. If you are the kind of person who needs to sleep in complete darkness, this is not the hotel for you. Or don't get our room. There was only one large window, but the curtains for it left large gaps in the middle and to the sides. In the morning, we were awakened by the light coming in those large seams, as well as the violent flushing of the room next to ours. I am usually a very easy-going traveler. I don't throw hysterics or fits, and understand that some things are out of the hotel's control. But I have to say that I was pretty disappointed with our room at the Affinia 50, considering I paid $250 for it (which for NYC prices, isn't much, I know) but for $250, I expect to be able to sleep the night through without hearing traffic noises, bathroom noises or worry that the sink is overflowing with my upstairs neighbor's used Aveda mouthwash.Or, I don't expect to find needles on the floor. No, I'm not talking about syringes, but the kinds of needles that hold together a dress shirt in packaging. I found three pins on the floor, fortunately, I did not find them the hard way. One thing I did forget to mention is that my wife thought she could hear the neighbors having sex from the bathroom. I don't know if the neighbors were in their bathroom and the pipes were carrying the sounds of their carrying ons, but that was not something I needed to know. Or perhaps it was the TV and the permium entertainment options which so many hotels depend on for revenue. Maybe someone upstairs ordered the $29.99 midnight to noon porn-a-thon and was making sure he got his money's worth. Despite all these issues, we did have a great time in New York. I'm actually willing to stay at the Affinia 50 again, provided that when I make the reservation, I get a high floor room. It was nice to have the extra space, but I really would have liked to have slept well last night. As it is, it's 9:20 now, and I'm ready for bed.  
<Date>Jul 10, 2005

<Author>Smally
<Content>Super Place Had an excellant stay at the Affina 50 for my wifes 30th birthday. Got off to a great start when Sid at the check in counter was able to immeadiately wish my wife happy birthday and then found us a great room on the 18th floor with a baclony giving us a nice view of the city. I had sent a request ahead of time for a room with a view but you never really think these things are acted on. Well at the Affina 50 it was and this attention to detail was really appreciated by us. The room was suprisingly spacious given everything I had heard about the size of rooms in NYC. Everything was very clean and the bathroom was pristine. We ordered our pillows from the menu and they were there when we got back that night (together with a card and a bottle of wine for my wife). The bed was very comfortable. To be honest I cannot think of one thing that was negative against this hotel.If you are not sure, go ahead and book it as I doubt you will be dissapointed.

<Author>2travelinfools
<Content>50 Cheers for the Affinia! We spent May 25th through May 30th at the Affinia 50 on our first trip to New York City. We were made to feel comfortable and welcome from the moment we checked in until we grudgingly left. When we called to confirm our reservation two weeks ahead, we were asked if we would prefer a lower or higher level room. We are very happy that we opted for the higher level as we were given a room on a corner of the 18th floor overlooking 3rd Avenue and 50th Street. We had beautiful view from our shared balcony of the city. We had a standard room with a huge, incredibly comfortable, king-sized bed. Our daughter and her fiance came up with us when we arrived to check in the hotel. Our future son-in-law works for a well-known hotel on Lexington and he was even amazed at the quality and amenties provided by the Affinia. As for the huge bed, after a night of dining and bar-hopping, three of us were able to take a nap comfortably on it, while hubby napped on the lounger before we all took in the Yankee game later that night. The Affinia is close to the Subway, Times Square, Rockfeller Center and St. Patrick's Cathedral. As a matter of fact, pretty much everything you can cram in a few days is within walking distance. Even the Gray line tour picks up and drops off 2 blocks away next to the Waldorf hotel. We highly recommend the tour for 1st timers as you can get off/on for 2 days/nights as much as you like, cramming in all the sightseeing you can stand for $48 a person. All in all we had a wonderful time in Gotham City. Everyone from the hotel staff to people in the subways were very friendly and helpful to we two small town mice scurrying around town trying to take in as much as we could.  
<Date>Jun 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Clean rooms, polite staff, perfect location! I've only just got round to writing this review - 5 months after we stayed at the Affinia 50! My girlfriend and I booked this place for a long weekend, and it was excellent. On entering the hotel, the reception looks a little dark and in need of some modernisation. The lift and corridors also looked a little dated, but the room was great, with a bed big enough to lose your partner in! It was also spotlessly clean and well maintained. The staff were so polite (rare for New Yorkers I think!) and nothing was too much trouble. As far as location was concerned, we were in walking distance of Time Square, The Rockefeller Centre, MOMA, Park Lane, 5th Avenue, etc, etc. It wasn't the Ritz, and I'm sure if we'd paid a lot more, we could have got somewhere a little more fashionable...............but to be honest, it was just right.

<Author>MSPKevin
<Content>Another satisfied customer We spent Memorial Day weekend in New York, 4 nights at the Affinia 50. I'd reserved a 1 bedroom non-smoking and was upgraded on arrival to a 1+ BR, 18th floor, but not non-smoking :-( The bed was very comfortable. We requested memory foam pillows but they were not available any of our 4 nights. The standard pillows were above average. Bathroom was also great - plenty of water pressure, decent sized tub, Aveda shampoo, conditioner, lotion and mouthwash.The room was clean, modern decor, overlooking 50th Street. TINY (maybe 5x8 feet) but functional kitchen - refrigerator, range, dishwasher, microwave, toaster, coffee pot, pots, pans and silverware - and a corkscrew. Yes, you can still bring a bottle of wine or 2 on a plane. There's a real grocery store 2 blocks away, 51st St. and 2nd Ave. We cooked breakfast 3 days but I doubt we really saved any money. There are 2 restaurants on 50th that serve breakfast for under $15 per person. We didn't do the Affinia continental breakfast based on Trip Advisor comments.Also on the same block - The Benjamin (50th and Lexington, Affinia's NYC flagship), The Kimberly (middle of 50th), The San Carlos (across the street from Kimberly). There's a Doubletree around the corner on Lexington, and the Waldorf-Astoria is on 49th, if money is no object. Expedia's map shows the hotel in the middle of the block, but it's not - it's on the corner of 50th and 3rd. We thought the Affinia 50 was a great value.The #6 subway station is at 51st and Lexington, and we rode every day. Great way to get north and south in Manhattan. Broadway (Times Square) is a 20 minute walk, or you can hop-hop-hop on trains or buses. We had excellent weather so we walked all over, probably 15 miles, including around the reservoir in Central Park. Dining in NYC - thousands of choices... the Blue Fin (W hotel in Times Square) was great, others were ok. Little Italy looked fun, lots of outdoor tables, but we'd just eaten in Chinatown.If you go and your cabbie doesn't know the hotel, have him go to 50th and Lexington, then left (East) on 50th. Better yet, take a limo - but get a coupon on the internet first. It should cost $25 plus toll ($5 for the tunnel), plus tip.We'll be back. I love Trip Advisor - thanks to all the other reviewers!  
<Date>Jun 6, 2005

<Author>Gslade
<Content>Fantastic- a home from home My partner and I stayed at the Affinia 50 between May 28 and June 1, 2005. We had originally booked to stay at the Waldorf but got a good rate for the Affinia 50 and thought we would save some money by changing our reservation. I was extremely glad we had too! Ok the lobby is small, but it looks good and every person who served us was genuinely friendly and helpful- from the cup of welcome punch- a welcome relief from the hot sun in New York, to the small fridge in our room- which was empty and great for cans of drink etc- and not at exorbitant minibar prices- well I give this 5 stars- if you can get a good rate. We were in a small queen bed room which although not a suite- was strill huge and well equipped from aveda toiletries, fab cable tv with many channels, coffee making service with wolfgang puck coffee and the lovely second floor lounge where we were happy to sit whilst waiting for our car to theairport once we had checked out. The Affinia 50 is almost on the same block as the Waldorf and extremely handy for the 51st street subway station which stops at almost every place of interest- from Grand Central, union Square, Chinatown, City Hall etc- so convenient and cheap as well. Round the corner from the Affinia is the 17th precinct police station and a fire station- so there is a generally safe feel to the place too. There are plenty of places to eat nearby including a nice coffeeshop, steak houses, mcdonalds, korean grocers with plenty of goodies on offer and you can get to many other places by foot. I cannot wait to go back and would recommend this place- i have stayed at many NY hotels over the years- Hilton New yrok, Hilton Millennium, Swissotel, Embassy Suites, Waldorf Astoria, habitat- but these folks were the genuine real deal- try it- you wont regret it!  
<Date>Jun 6, 2005

<Author>schippk
<Content>Wonderful Hotel, Wonderful Town Unbeknownst the management, the Affinia 50 has ensured my future happiness as a traveler married to an ex-New Yorker.My husband left his native city 30 years ago, vowing never to return to the riots, crime, garbage strikes and other mayhem typical of Manhattan in the '70s. I, on the other hand, had visited the city on my own six years ago and was absolutely smitten with it. Years of repetitive marital suggestions on my part finally wore down my better half's resistance, and he grudgingly agreed to return briefly to the Big Apple with me. I immediatly launched into a frenzy of Internet searching for just the right hotel to make good on my promise that a trip to New York would in no way resemble a holiday in Hades. Late into the night, I pored over TripAdvisor reviews in a growing state of alarm: The most expensive hotels gauranteed a plush experience but were far beyond our budget. Some of the cheapest places sounded positively Dickensian, with levels of filth and discomfort that a midieval peasant would have found unacceptable. Reviews of the Affinia 50 sounded too good to be true: In the heart of Midtown where I wanted to stay, lovely rooms and courteous staff, at a reasonable price. I crossed my fingers and booked.A few weeks later, as our cab crawled through traffic from JFK toward Manhattan, the sight of the Chrysler Building glittering on the horizon wasn't quite enough to keep me from silently planning how we could escape if the Affinia 50 turned out not be as advertised. Could we find another hotel? Stay in New Jersey? Fly home early? Would I ever see my beloved Manhattan again?Well, I needn't have worried. From the stylish exterior (my husband is an architect an we are both fans of modern design, so we liked the stainless-steel awning and towering indoor waterfall in the lobby) to the smiles on the faces of the fedora-clad doormen, we were delighted from the moment we stepped over the threshold. Not only did the hotel have our reservation (another fear of mine), they upgraded us at no charge from a standard room to a junior suite. As we rode up in the elevator, I reminded my husband that rooms on New York are small. In this respect, the Affinia did make a liar of me: our room was immense, with a sitting area, a full small kitchen, a good-sized bathroom, huge closets, and sweeping picture windows across the entire south wall. As we gazed down across a plaza to the famous Smith and Wollensky steakhouse, my husband grinned from ear to ear and said, This is great!Although the building is older, everything in our room was new, appearing to be no more than a couple of years old. Our bed had crisp luxury linens and the most comfortable mattress I have ever had the privilege of sleeping on. The bathroom had ultramodern fixtures (not in the scary, what-is-this-button-for mode, but understated elegance) with Aveda bath products and huge pillowy towels. The office area had a high-speed data connection that we did not use, but we did use the living room with overstuffed chairs, large-screen TV and sofa. We also liked the CD player, popping in discs that we bought on our shopping expeditions through Manhattan's music stores. The Affinia does not have a restaurant, but we did not care as we usually try to eat in as many different places as possible when we travel. There is an absolutely amazing deli called Azure around the corner from the hotel. Several nights, when we had worn our feet down to little stubs walking through museums and galleries, we were content to curl up on our comfy sofa with heaping portions of pad thai and a couple of cold beers from the deli and just watch TV. The hotel also offers continental breakfast for an additional $10 per night, but the deli was so convenient and such good value that we just went there instead. Every morning I got up, got dressed, went out past the cheerful doormen who would tip their fedoras to me, elbowed my way into the streaming throngs of non-tourist New Yorkers, and made for Azure to pick up coffee and pain au chocolate. I would then return to the room, where we sat in the fabulous bed marveling at our good fortune. The only drawback to this routine was that it cut in to sightseeing time, as we got so comfortable we could hardly pry ourselves out of our room. Each morning we would vow to get going before 10:00, but it rarely happened.Late in our stay we discovered that the hotel has wine and cheese available for guests every evening. Again, we did not take advantage of this amenity as we were usually still out sightseeing due to the above-mentioned late start.During our stay, there was only one annoyance, which was not the hotel's fault. The building across the street was being renovated, and some of the work was being done late at night, resulting in pounding and large diesel-engine-idling noises, rather like those of a garbage truck. I think this sort of thing is nearly unvoidable in Manhattan, so I would encourage anyone who does not travel with earplugs to do so. We heard no other street noises from our sixth-floor room nor did we hear any sound from any other rooms.The Affinia's location is one of its major advantages. If you're reasonably energetic, you can easily walk to Fifth Avenue, Rockefeller Center, the south end of Central Park, and Grand Central Station. There are also several subway entrances near the hotel. There are too many restaurants in the neighborhood to list, but fans of Irish pubs as my husband and I are will find the number of these establishments within a few blocks to be nothing short of overwhelming. We also had an outstanding and thoroughly real New York experience dining at Smith and Wollensky, made all the more pleasant by being able to walk across the street to the restaurant.The Affinia's neighborhood is quite safe, and I would have had no concern whatsover about walking around alone at night.My only complaint about the hotel was that we were unable to extend our stay, as they were thoroughly booked. The staff made immense efforts to accommodate our request, but there was never a cancellation. After four days at the Affinia, I certainly can understand why. Nevertheless, I'm overjoyed as the person who was trying the hardest to get the additional time was my husband. We'll be back!  
<Date>Jun 5, 2005

<Author>seaorski
<Content>Great location, clean and friendly This was our first trip to New York. It was my daughter's 21st birthday and this was a special trip for her. We arrived late the first night and were put into a room with one bed which was a disappointment as I had called that morning to confirm that they had 2 beds for us. They made up for it the next 2 nights by giving us a junior suite (kitchenette and 2 queen beds) at no extra charge. The rooms were spacious, modern and tastefully decorated. The Aveda products were a bonus. All the staff at the front desk got to know us by our names and went out of their way with recommendations for restaurants/clubs and with directions. It was a pleasant atmosphere to come and go to. The second floor had a cozy sitting area with books and games and wide screen T.V. This came in handy when our flight was later than our checkout time and we needed a place where we could relax. They also serve continental breakfast here every morning. The location was within comfortable walking distance to major shopping, Central Park, the theatre district, Rockefeller center. The restaurant right next door had delicious seafood and steak dinners and a great atmosphere. Our only complaint was that the cleaning staff were overly zealous to get our rooms cleaned in the mornings. We had traveled east so had not yet adjusted to the 3 hour time change. We were repeatedly woken up and couldn't find a 'do not disturb' sign anywhere in the room to hang on the door. What we really liked about the Affinia was that it felt like a small hotel with personalized service in a big city. We look forward to revisiting New York in the future and will defintely stay at the Affinia again.  
<Date>Jun 5, 2005

<Author>phylisfjohnson
<Content>What a wonderul find! I have stayed at The Plaza, The St. Regis and The Waldorf. They were all dumps compared to The Affina 50.Our entire stay was a delight. From the unbelievably accommodating staff....to the well equipped kitchen (complete with fridge, stove and microwave)...and the thoughtfully stocked bathroom (terry robes and Aveda products)...to the luxurious beds (with 3 choices of pillows)...the comfy couch and easy chair and the easy-to-read-by lighting. Even the CD left by the Sony Dream Machine was perfect.This particular Affina hotel is centrally located at 50th between Lexington and 3rd. There are 6 other Affina hotels spread out from the 30's to the 70's, so you're likely to find one in just the right location -- whether you're in NY for business, theatre, shopping, restaurant hopping or visiting friends. Whichever one you choose, I'm sure your Affina hotel experience will enhance your stay. After 30 years of dreading going into the City, I'm now actually looking forward to my next trip to New York!  
<Date>Jun 4, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Hotel in NYC for Quality, Comfort and Price On arrival at The Affinia 50 my partner and i got a wonderful welcome from the concierge, Welcome home, he said as he lifted our bags and helped us through the doors.The check in was quick. The lobby, small but well presented. We stayed on the 9th floor and what a wonderful junior suite room we had. It was perfect for our week stay and was sometimes hard to leave due to the wonderful decor and comfort. No view though as we were almost up against a wall but this left the room extremely quiet. The kitchen was the only let down as it wasn't done to the standard of the rest of the room but we didn't use it much so it didn't matter.We were rushing around sightseeing all day and were extremely tired and couldn't wait to rest our weary feet but i do have to say the bed was the most comfortable i have ever slept in in my life. We were asleep as soon as our heads touched the pillow (although i didn't use the pillow as it was a little on the large side). The water in my bath wasn't the hottest and neither was the temperature of the room but i'm sure if we'd have contacted the front desk they'd have had it sorted in no time.The concierge were great, always there to open doors and welcome you home. Ralph deserves a special mention for organising our helicopter flight, which was magnificent and definately advised for spectacular views of the city. Each day we would return to a well cleaned room. The maids were spotless. The 2nd floor lounge is well worth a look if you want somewhere to chill out for a bit too.A little way out on the east side from Times Square but not far from Rockerfeller and Chrysler building. Subway is just around the corner and taxis are along every few seconds.All in all the Affinia 50 has been my favourite hotel to date. Well recommended. Just go there and see. Cheers.  
<Date>May 12, 2005

<Author>Freckles
<Content>Vastly overrated on Tripadvisor When I was deciding on a hotel for this trip to NYC, I picked the Affinia 50 because of its superb tripadvisor.com reviews. Now, having stayed there for 2 nights I wonder if those rave reviews were actually written by a PR firm or Affinia employees. Seriously! This hotel is adequate but nothing even close to great. It was in the low 80s Farenheit while I was in New York and I prefer to sleep in cool temperatures. I called downstairs to see what could be done, as the thermastat (sp?) was as low as it could go and the room was still too warm for my tastes. I was told open your windows. Um. This is hardly a solution when the street noise is so loud that it awakens you in the mornings even with your windows shut.The lobby was tiny, but that didn't bother me in the least since as far as I can tell, lobbies are a waste of money/space. And the aveda products in my teeny bathroom were lovely. The staff was friendly. But overall the hotel was utterly unimpressive and I will not stay there again unless I get a much better price.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Affinia a disappointment I picked the Affinia 50 because of its positive TripAdvisor reviews, but the hotel was a disappointment. I asked for a quiet room, but was given a room on a low floor, between the stairs and the elevator, and directly above the exhaust fans for a nearby business; I expected to have to pay for Internet access, and while they did provide a network cable, there was no place to plug it in--the room had never been wired for Internet; I expected a kitchenette and got just a coffeemaker; heck, I expected functioning air conditioning, but that was broken too! On a day when the outside temperature peaked at 60 degrees, the room was 80 degrees all night long. (And forget opening the windows for ventilation; the noise from the nearby fans was enough to prevent conversation with the windows open.) On the positive side, the room was spacious for New York, the bed was comfortable (down duvet, synthetic pillows), and everything was clean. I'm never staying here again.  
<Date>May 9, 2005

<Author>Relaxseeker
<Content>Affinia 50 for you'all!! We stayed in Affinia 50 for a whole week. At first I was a little bit concerned, since I've been visiting New York 30 years ago and any dirt-hole in NY might ask for US$200.00 a night, so price is not a good filter. When we arrived to Affinia 50 the staff was very helpful and very professional, the room was very good, a little sober, but for the price I wasn't dissapointed at all. This hotel is one of the smartest choices. The location is a little bit back east, but not that bad, within 8 minutes you are in Rockefeller Center. Please don't misunderstand, this is not a luxury hotel, it's an affordable, clean, well located and well staffed hotel for so to speak.If you are visiting New York on a tight budget this is your choice, don't look further. I've seen hotels asking for the same and there is not comparison, this is the place.If you are looking 5 stars and a fancy hotel I would recommend The Benjamin or The Peninsula, and guess what... The Benjamin is an Affinia hotel and is barely 50 meters from Affinia 50, so if you are staying for 5 nights and stay in Affinia 50 Instead, you might save enough to buy a nice sport jacket at Brook Brothers or a Dinner for 6 at Gramercy Tavern, so you do your math. :)

<Author>muttger
<Content>Affinia Exceeds expectations The Affinia 50 lives up to and even exceeds expectations! This is a wonderful hotel whose outstanding feature is the personnel and service along with the accomodations. We stayed in a very comfortable queen double on the 14th floor. The beds were so comfortable that we had to tear ourselves away. Midtown location is very convenient to theatre district and Rockefeller Center. Every request or question was met with a friendly and efficient answer and our greeting and check-in could not have been handled better. I felt that the staff went out of their way to make our stay the best it could be and it was! The second floor club room was very roomy and offered a comfortable place to hang out and work or just relax. I would definitely stay here again except I would request a room in the back of the hotel as it remained quite noisy throughout the night.

<Author>mgonzo2u
<Content>1st Big Apple visit enhanced greatly by Affinia 50 Based on my due diligence in searching for a quality location/hotel, I figured the Affinia 50 had something special going for it because the reviews were clearly leaning towards the positive side. I can now confirm for the rest of you first hand that the glowing reviews are for good reason. Although this hotel is noted in several publication as an executive class hotel, I booked my family of 3 (my wife, a 17 mo old daughter and myself) for a family vacation. The website photos for the Affinia 50 do not do it justice. The corner location is brilliant. The hotel lobby, albeit smaller in comparison to other hotels, appears brand spanking new and makes up for lack of quatitive lobby space with superior small space aesthetics.The one bedroom suite I booked online thru Travelocity (via Tripadvisor.com of course) with specific requests for a non-smoking room with a view and a high chair for the baby were all flawlessly met upon check-in. The full amenity kitchen was used alot. The added value of the kitchen paid for itself by allowing me to make sit down breakfasts for us every day of our stay from 4/24-4/27/05. The 15th floor room (#1505) turned out to be a corner room suite overlooking E. 50th St and 3rd Ave.. Talk about a view! My wifes brother and his young family met us at our hotel room so as to join us for dinner in the area and with his two kids and my kid all running around the room, everyone still had plenty of space to move around freely. I was advised by my brother in law (who is familiar w/ Manhattan) that the room, had it been an apt for rent, would easily fetch $5k per month and that the size of the room was easily 2-3 times larger than most NYC hotel rooms. Needless to say, he was impressed by my hotel find for someone that had never been to NY, much less Manhattan.The location of the hotel was of course great. Subway entrances are located nearby (1 to 1 1/2 blocks away). There are every possible assortment of convenient stores available to you for food and drink all within the square block of the hotel. That aspect alone is worth the stay when traveling with a young child. Got milk? Sure do, right down stairs and around the corner (24/7).  All of the tourist attractions people from all over the world come to NYC to see are all within striking distance of this hotel, be it by an inexpensive taxi, subway, bus ride or even a nice walk. We walked to Times Square 3 different times from the hotel and we didn't even have to breathe hard doing it (even while pushing the kid in a stroller). The #6 subway (a block from the hotel) will take you down to great ethnic areas like Little Italy and China Town in about 15-20 minutes. The food to be found in just those two areas alone are to die for and we all know how NYC is regarded for its food options. Just imagine all the great palate pleasing possibilities available to you. I could go on and on but I think you now know where I am coming from in regards to this hotel. And of course a hotel of this quality is only as good as THEIR STAFF and they DID NOT DISAPPOINT. The staff was friendly, attentive and spot on with all their advice/recommendations pertaining to the city in which they do business. Oh, and the rooms, spotless. Housekeeping was outstanding with the daily refresh.If you reserve a room at the Affinia 50, you will find out just as we did that NYC has more to offer than world renowned attractions, it also has hotels that price themselves right and are staffed by friendly folks that make your stay more than a vacation, they give you a feeling of being home away from home.Cheers to the Affinia 50!FYI, Cheers! is the slogan the staff uses throughout the hotel to meet and greet its residents.  
<Date>Apr 28, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Just right Good location (walking distance to Bloomingdale's, Madison, Park, 5th etc.). Affable, likeable staff. Our room was small (c'mon, it's New York), but very tastefully furnished/decorated. We didn't make use of any breakfasts or other amenities so I can't comment on those. Don't expect luxurious space and panoramic views here, but if you are looking to spend your day in town and not lounge about in a luxury hotel, this is a very tasteful, comfortable and conveniently located hotel. There is a nightclub next door so that might be a problem for some, but we couldn't hear anything from our particular room.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good value, great bed, terrific staff We booked the Affinia 50 as a result of all the glowing reviews on this website. We were not disappointed, though I have one quibble: multiple reviewers mentioned being upgraded at check-in. Though I had said in advance it was our wedding anniversary, which I repeated when we arrived, no upgrade for us. (I later learned the hotel was sold-out.) The hotel did send up a complimentary bottle of wine, however. Nice touch. My husband ordered flowers for me through the hotel, specifying what type of flowers he wanted included in the arrangement, and they were gorgeous. (They used a local florist.) The room was extremely comfortable, fantastic bed, great fixtures in the small bathroom (very good water pressure), wonderfully nice staff. The full-length mirror takes at least 10 pounds off, BTW - a good ego boost going out the door! Loved the cocktail hour (free) in the Eurofab stylish 2nd floor lounge. We didn't try the $10 per person continental breakfast - wonder why it ends so early (930 during the week, 1030 on the weekends)? Food smells pervaded the room when we opened our window, but we were on the 3rd floor - maybe this isn't an issue on higher floors. I'd definitely go back, but only if the price stayed at $200 or less per night.  
<Date>Apr 14, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good location, nice people, great room  My wife and I stayed at the Affinia 50 for our wedding anniversary weekend. Our room was large (by NYC standards), comfortable and quiet. We both thought that the bed was one of the more comfortable hotel beds we have ever experienced. The room was clean and remarkably quiet, the bathroom adequate (smallish, but it is NYC), the appointments in good shape. The staff was both very friendly and very helpful. The location was terrific. The cock-tail hour in the lounge was very pleasant. One small complaint, we stayed in the first week of April. The day we arrived had been a hot one but the building鈥檚 air conditioner was not yet operative (not too unusual in an older building in NYC, but annoying nonetheless). Our first night (of three) was very warm and it being NYC, you really can鈥檛 leave the windows open or the street noise will be too much. However, after the temperature returned to a more normal zone the next day, the room was perfectly comfortable. In short, be careful during transitional months. Also, while our room was very clean, etc. the hall smelled of cigarettes. We got a great price and would definitely stay here again.  
<Date>Apr 11, 2005

<Author>girlnoir
<Content>Not lakely to saty here again... My husband and I stayed here in February 2005 for one night and had a fairly unpleasant experience. We got a great deal from americanexpress and the reviews in tripadvisor seemed good. We had a standard room, not a suite. It was very tiny with hardly any where to put our bags, except an easy chair and a desk. The room was newly furnished with modern furniture, but was very dim. There was a stong smell of french fries in the room the whole time we where there, presumable form a neighboring restaurant. Our room over looked a brick wall and a roof with chimney  ducts, etc. The shower drain was broken and water backed up to our ankles. If we had be staying longer we would have certainly changed rooms, if not hotels. Valet parking is $35 and it took 1.5 hrs to get my car, even tough we called a half an hour ahead of when we needed it, like we were told to do. The club room is pretty nice, but continental breakfast is $10 pp.The staff were nice, however, especially the hard working bellhops. The lobby is tiny and got quite crowded at check in/ out time.

<Author>Wanderlust58
<Content>the other reviewers were right. Just stayed here one night over Easter weekend. I thought rate of $169 through hotel was good for a newly renovated hotel in a good location. I would consider this a business persons hotel, with the internet connection and lots of outlets. The style is modern. But very comfortable for my husband and I, in for the weekend. Average size room, nicely furnished, king bed, down comforter with a pillow menu available. Closet space good. No restaurant or bar in hotel, plenty nearby, but a club floor with lounge and for $10 p.p. there is an expanded continental breakfast available (juice, fresh fruit, cereals, bagels, pastries, coffee, tea). Walked to the theatre, 2 subways nearby for other parts of town. This is not a 5 star luxury hotel nor a too cool for school trendy hotel, but a very pleasant hotel with nice staff.

<Author>mpjc121
<Content>What a Gem This hotel is a gem of a find in a city that has a lot to offer. We booked for one night only and I was sad that we couldn't stay longer but I hope to stay there again on my next trip down. The hotel itself is very non descript from the outside but once you step inside, what a find it is. The young doorman is a character but has some great recommendations for local restaurants delis etc and always had such a genuine smile and warmth for all the guests. The design style in the rooms is very warm and comfortable and the bed was first class, I hated getting up in the morning. The bathrooms are beautiful and the bath products (Aveda) top class. I could not find one fault with the room, it is just like the photos show. The chill out area on the second floor is a wonderful space to relax after a tough day to read a book with a nice drink to accompany it. Diana (or Dyana) at the front desk is wonderful and immediately located an Aveda store locally where I was able to purchase some of the same bath products they have in the guestrooms. Nothing was to much trouble for the staff here, they were all just superb. This hotel serves as a model of customer service, comfort and excellent value for money. I have found my new home in NYC when I visit.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Mixed! I can understand why so many reviews are positive -- this hotel is in a good location, the staff are super-friendly and very on the ball, and the bed is wonderfully comfortable. But I found a number of things off. * We were supposedly in a non-smoking room, but the room stunk, and the staff member who brought up an ozone machine forgot to turn it on, so it accomplished nothing while we were out the day we first requested it.* The puce blinds had water stains on them and vehemently clashed with the red and beige arm chair. In a budget hotel, this wouldn't bother me, but in a hotel that styles itself as luxurious, the stains were unacceptable and the style choices startlingly bad.* The bathtub drain was broken.* The noise from the hallway is unbelievable. Don't think about sleeping in. The doors are weighted so heavily that you'll be woken up by one door after another slamming as other guests leave their rooms. You will also have to listen to the housekeeping staff knocking on other doors and yelling out at other guests before they get to your room.* The desk is huge, so you feel as if you are sleeping in an office. If you're in New York on business, you might very well appreciate the size of the desk. But if you're there for romance, you'll feel stuck in the work-a-day world!In conclusion, while this is a decent hotel, it is over-priced. You could certainly do worse, but you could also certainly do better. If you do book this hotel, make sure you get a rate that is at least half of the rack rate (as we did) or else you're likely to feel that you have misspent your money.  
<Date>Mar 25, 2005

<Author>geoff66
<Content>Warm your gloves... Stayed March18 to 21, 2005. Read the other reviews, they are almost dead on. Location great, staff excellent, good value, clean, and so on. Well, almost and so on. I have a couple of quibles, and that is really all they are. Firstly, on the Affiinia Website this hotel is rated in their 'Signature' series, implying the top range. In fact, the Benjamin, which is virtually next door, looked like a more appealing hotel, although, having not stayed there I base this observation solely on a comparison of the lobbies of the two facilities. The Affinia's is decidedly cramped. Secondly, a major oversight in the renovation of the rooms was the kitchen...at least in our junior suite. It is the size of a broom closet, and features rather tired looking cupboards, counters, appliances AND the tiniest microwave oven I've ever encountered. Like the size of a glovebox. In fact, it might have been a glovebox. If you review the photo gallery on their website you will notice photos of the kitchen are conspicous in their absence. OK, enough kretching, I actually enjoyed the place, the staff seem to really make an effort. The doormen, especially, with their signature fedoras, add a stylish touch. Plus, the beds were the 'bomb', as my teenage daughter would say. (This is a compliment) I would stay again.  
<Date>Mar 22, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Clean, Convenient, Good Value I stayed at the Affinia for 2 nights in February. The location is very good. Close to the subway, and just a couple of blocks from Saint Patrick's Cathedral. The hotel was very recently renovated; thus, it is fresh and clean. The gym is modest. I got a fantastic special through Quikbook ($179.00 including breakfast for a junior suite), but I was traveling in low season. The room was cavernous by New York standards; perfect for families (I wish mine had been traveling with me). The breakfast is simple (fruit, pastries), but perfectly adequate. If you do not have it included, the charge is $10.00 extra-I would not pay anymore than that. The wine and cheese in the evenings is again very simple (no plates for the cheese, you had to use napkins, a disappointment), but a nice touch before heading out to dinner. I was disappointed that the room adjoining the lounge was used for private events on both my nights there; it made the lounge a little crowded. My room had no view, but was very quiet. The doorman was very friendly. The renovations are very nice, but not overly luxurious (tile instead of marble in the bathrooms). All in all, I have paid substantially more in New York for smaller, less well-kept accomodations. I would go back.  
<Date>Mar 16, 2005
<Rating>4	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1

<Author>gill052
<Content>Affinia 50- great deal, great location If you're looking for a great location and a good deal (my experience), then look into the Affinia 50 at 50th and Third Ave. A block from the Waldorf (where our conference was sited), and less than half the price. New rooms, cool furnishings, great amenities and loads of space. Easily twice the space in a guest room than the Waldorf. By using Expedia (can I say that?) I got two nights at $179 per. $10 for the buffet bkfst (save yer dough, there's plenty of bkfst joints w/in two blocks). NO RESTAURANT on premises, but it's NYC fer cryin' out loud. For business travellers there is Smith  Wollensky a block away, for the more budget minded there's pasta places, burger joints, pubs, and Indian restaurants within a 5 min walk. Staff is amazing. Super well trained, professional and courteous.  
<Date>Mar 15, 2005

<Content>Nice NYC Niche I just returned from a three day weekend stay with my teenage daughter and her friend. We were very happy with our room, which was clean and comfortable. We would definitely stay there again.

<Author>faige
<Content>Close Call Just got back from a mini vacation at the Affinia 50. Was very inpressed with the size of the room considering it's a Manhattan hotel and the full kitchen! The room was great until we had no heat and the initial hesitation on the part of the manager to not be very helpful except to offer a portable heater. Upon visiting the room itself and seeing my children shivering under the blankets she did offer me the night complimentary and moved us the next day as soon as a room became available. We also had difficulty renting movies as they were all sold out, a phenomenon I had never experienced in a hotel . Still I would return to this hotel and highly recommend it for it's low rates and great room and location in NYC

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent stay! We booked a junior suite, complete with a kitchenette, it was more than I imagined, and for a rate of $159.00, got much more than what we paid for. We were on the 8th floor, the rooms were spotless, and nicely decorated with plenty of closet space! The bed was super comfy, with down pillows, a down comforter and featherbed type mattress....There was plenty of room to move around, this is wonderful (especially for NYC....). The rooms were recently renovated with a modern (but comfortable) edge to it....loved the decor! Bath amenities were by Aveda (which is wonderful quality salon products). I will also say the employees were very friendly and accomodating also. Great staff!!! It has a small lobby, but who needs a huge lobby?? It serves it's purpose....we were taken care of and all checked in within 5-10 minutes!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>One of the best stays in New York City ever The Affinia 50 Hotel has everything going for it. For the same price as a room at the Hilton or Sheraton, you can have a clean, large one-bedroom suite. They are basically apartments with a full kitchen, large bedroom and the great Affinia bed.   One thing many people don't think about (or maybe don't care about) is the number of electric outlets in a hotel room. Well, Affinia 50 has this covered - I had no problem finding a place to plug in 2 cell phones, my Mom's Palm Pilot and my T-Mobile Sidekick device.  I think one of the best things about the Affinia 50 is the incredibly friendly, courteous and professional staff. Even though I was only there for 2 days, I felt as though I had acquired extended family members!   I would highly recommend this hotel and cannot wait to stay there again.   
<Date>Feb 11, 2005

<Content>ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL!! My first stay was Nov. 20, 2004. I booked a one bedroom suite. Quite to my surprise the rooms were HUGE. The rooms had a sleek modern decor  were very clean. It was like a home away from home. I was extremely pleased. Shortly after my stay, I receive a letter from Affinia 50 apologizing for the unexpected inconveniences . They offered me a complimentary upgrade for my next stay at the hotel. I took them up on their offer for a stay on January 5, 2005. I called and spoke to the manager Silvio about the letter I received. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>This Hotel Is Awesome!!!!! My husband and I spent several days at the Affina 50 in Dec '04. It takes alot to impress me--and I was!! This hotel is spotless, the staff, all of them, went above and beyond to assure our every need was met. The rooms are huge--we had a junior suite, which was more room than we needed but after a full day of walking etc it was great to relax and have some personal space to boot! The beds were a dream to sleep on, the windows opened, the bathrooms are huge and the kitchen was a great room to have complete with coffee etc. The sofa and chairs were comfortable and I could find not one spec of dirt anywhere!! The linen was spotless. The price was very reasonable--and when we arrived the room was just as we had reserved--no surprises.My son had booked us a room at the Metropolitin, but after I read the reviews I was too concerned so changed ours to the Affinia 50. I was so happy I did as they had one disappointment after another at their hotel.We were just around the corner from them so it worked out great. I can't count how many times the kids said to us that they wished they had booked at the Affinia 50--but they just thought the Trip Advisor site was a bunch of people that had nothing better to do and would complain about just anything. Well--they are believers now!!We are from WA State and really wanted our trip to be special--and it was!! Thanks in large part to our wonderful time at the Affinia 50.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved Affinia 50 My husband and I looked online for hotels in NY for days and we read countless reviews on this site to help us decide where to stay. Because it is Dec., everything we had read good things about was booked up. We had the smallest room they have but it was still spacious, especially compared to other hotels in NY. The room was lovely and the bed was very comfortable. The staff couldn't have been more hospitable. We had great service and we loved every minute of our stay. We will definitely stay at the Affinia 50 again.

<Author>Vgbnd
<Content>New York Surprise! My recent stay at the Affinia 50 was such a pleasant surprise, I feel compelled to write this review. There were many great things about the Affinia 50 that made my stay there special, and make it an excellent hotel:o Doorman - The gentleman there during the weeknights always had a smile on his face, recognized me, and made sure I didn't walk in the wrong direction. Best doorman I've ever met in New York, this after thirty years of frequent flyer traveling. He wears a distinctive grey derby.o Spaciousness - Unlike the typical NY city hotel, the rooms here are generously sized. It felt like the living room of a comfortable New York co-op.o Decor - Comfortable furnishings, the best bed and bedding I've ever had in a hotel. Most hotels have sterile lighting and fixtures. The Affinia 50 has modern variable intensity lighting on many fixtures, and they have been generous in wattage. The bathroom was very clean, well-equipped, and spacious. o Kitchen - When booking, I did not really realize that my unit would have a full-service kitchen, with refrigerator, microwave, stove-top and dishwasher! Comes equipped with table settings.o Location - Close to subways, and some great restaurants. If you like Italian cuisine, try nearby Giambelli's. They're still serving dishes where you can taste that $41,000 Italian white truffle they had won in a charity auction.o Staff - All in all, the best staff I've ever met in a New York hotel. From the maid to the front desk, always a kind word and a way of making you feel special! Never stuffy, just plain friendly and responsive. From check-in to check-out, it was amazingly consistent.Even the best hotel room in the world is just a room, but it's the way they treat you at the Affinia 50 that make it a great hotel.  
<Date>Dec 4, 2004

<Author>PreciseTR
<Content>Absolutely Loved Plaza Fifty After much research online and reading reviews on numerous Manhattan hotels, I finally picked Plaza Fifty. There were eight of us: 1 studio suite w/two people, and 2 junior suites w/three each. The hotel rooms were all newly renovated, very large, and had extremely comfortable beds. Even the sofa bed was comfortable.The service we recieved was excellent and consistent over the six days we were there. This hotel is centrally located and within walking distance to major shopping, convenience/grocery stores, restaurants, and even night clubs.I couldn't believe the price we paid for the rooms. Even though I probably won't be able to get those prices again, I'm making Plaza Fifty my number one choice for my next NY visit.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Now the Affinia 50 Overall I really liked this hotel. It has its pros and cons, mostly pros, which I will address first.The Pros:Great location - 1 short block to the No. 6 lexington avenue subway line, this will get you everywhere from the Metropolitan Museeum of Art to Grand Central to Soho. Also, great neighborhood for convenient and good restaurants. We had really amazing Indian food at Jaipur on 2nd Ave. between 53rd and 54th Street. I am a huge fan of Indian food and very picky. Everything was excellent, especially the Chicken Tikka Masala.The price and the room - I don't know how much the prices fluctuate at this hotel but we got a great deal. $239 a night during peak season in Mid-October (we stayed 10/16-10/20 of 2004). This was for a one bedroom suite with kitchen that is larger than the Manhattan apartment I used to live in!The Club Room - they have a new common area club room on the 2nd floor. It offers complimentary bottled water, coffee and tea throughout the day and has several seating areas with big screen tv, fireplace, etc.. Mon - Thurs from 6pm to 7pm they have complimentary wine and cheese.The Cons:The hotel is not terribly upscale - the lobby is small and the staff while friendly is not very polished. However, it is very clean and all of the rooms were recently renovated as part of the re-opening of the Affinia 50. The renovation/redecoration while nice is on the cheap side ( the upholstery on the new couch had already started to tear - the carpet had stains).Overall if you can get this deal at this hotel do it. It's excellent, especially if you are traveling with children.  
<Date>Oct 19, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>My New Favorite in NYC This weekend was my second stay at the Plaza Fifty and it was EVEN better than my first. I figured that 2 great experiences in a row deserved a positive review. The first time I stayed there in April 2004, my boyfriend and I were pleasantly surprised by the large sized guest room we were given, which included a kitchenette area. We even had a great view from our windows of 3rd avenue. This is compared to other hotels that we have stayed in like Hotel 41, which is about the size of a closet and has a view of a wall. The icing on the cake was that we got the room at a special rate of about $140, a great deal for NY. The only complaint I had at the time was that the carpeting was a bright royal blue color. Other than that, the room was clean and the furniture was fine.This past Saturday night, my friend and I spent the night in the city and got a hotel room so that we didn't have to worry about catching the train home. Luckily, there were still rooms available at the Plaza Fifty, even though I called only a few days in advance. FYI, make sure you call the hotel since their online reservation system isn't always accurate. I ending up reserving our room through Travelocity since the rate was cheaper ($179). The best part came that night when we checked in. The awesome guy at the front desk (Sid? I think...) asked if it was our first time there and then asked who's birthday it was. My friend replied that it was her birthday about a month ago, and he went ahead and upgraded us to a junior suite! Apparently, the hotel is soon to be an executive club type hotel and was renovated in preparation. I knew the room would be big, but didn't know how amazing it would be...just renovated, all new furniture, a full-size kitchen with a table, the most comfortable hotel beds with down bedding, a balcony with a view, etc! It even smelled like a new room! We seriously could've lived there. Sid even called when we got upstairs to see what we thought of the room. Unfortunately, he wasn't working anymore by the time we were making our way out to the bars so we couldn't thank him again in person. But I hope that whoever is reading this will pass on the message to him and give him the credit that he deserves.All in all, I LOVE this hotel and am glad that I don't have to do anymore hotel researching for my trips to NY. I'm hoping that nothing about the hotel changes (I'm even willing to pay more if I know I'll enjoy my stay...) The staff is very friendly and helpful and the location is great (right near 2nd avenue bars/restaurants and only a few minute walk to 5th ave). It's definitely my favorite New York hotel!  
<Date>Sep 7, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>GREAT STAY AT THE PLAZA 50 Stayed June 10-14th. Nice hotel--close to major attractions and subway. Room included small microwave and fridge. Had to wash dishes (provided) in the bathroom sink but that was ok. Didn't use these as much as we intended because we were out most of day. True, there were renovations coing on but only was a slight problem when we came back in late afternoon to rest before going out for the evening. Had requested high room with view through Expedia and got the 4th floor with view of next building's wall and air conditioning unit. Disappointed because this was my first stay in NYC. Be specific on what you ask for (ie. view of street). Staff was friendly and helpful! Will stay again!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice Place to Stay We enjoyed our recent stay at the Plaza Fifty. It is convenient to Rockefeller Center and other midtown attractions but far enough off the beaten path to afford a good value (we paid $159/night). The staff was very friendly and accomodating. Note that they are in the midst of gutting and remodeling every floor with the majority slated to be executive suites. Our floor was one of the last awaiting the wrecker and we received a wake up call one morning as renovation began on the floor above. However, since we were getting out to enjoy the city it was not a major inconvenience. The staff showed us the new room format and it was very nice. However, expect the rates to go up as the new rooms go into service.   
<Date>Jun 8, 2004

<Author>TravelCat36
<Content>Pleasantly surprised! We had a great long weekend at the Plaza 50! My husband was in New Jersey for business so our children and I (8 yr old and 8 mo old) joined him in NYC for a long weekend. When we arrived at 3:30am they did not have a Jr. Suite available so we were upgraded to a 1 bedroom suite. It was beautiful! It was newly renovated and very large. The bathroom was small, but the kitchenette and large living room more than made up for it. The entire suite was impeccably clean. I have travelled many, many times and this by far was the nicest budget-minded hotel I have ever stayed in. The beds were extremely comfortable (new).The hotel lobby, hallways and elevators are not at all impressive and very small, but the large clean rooms are a pleasant surprise when you open the room door. We could not hear a peep from other guests through the walls or hallways.The other bad reviews must have gotten older rooms before they were renovated. Ours was perfect. We will definately stay there again.  
<Date>May 21, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Enjoyed my stay My husband and I have just returned from a pleasant stay at the Plaza Fifty (April 16-19, 2004). This hotel was recommended by a friend who has also stayed here. This was not my first visit to NYC, so I was expecting a small, run-down hotel room. I was pleasantly surprised at how roomy our studio suite was! It's not a brand new hotel, but it's clean and the rooms are spacious. I found the desk staff to be noticably nice and helpful during our stay. We stayed on the 8th floor overlooking 50th Street. It was a little noisy in the morning due to the street noise and I believe they were renovating rooms on the floor above us. We ate at the New York Luncheonette next door which was inexpensive and quick for breakfast. We also ate at the George O'Neill restaurant next door for dinner which was good. As others on this site have said, the location of this hotel is ideal. I would stay here again based on the size/cleanliness of the rooms, the price, and the location.  
<Date>Apr 21, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Very satsified I was nervous about booking online, sight unseen, but the reviews of this hotel were all extremely accurate. The hotel is clean and the staff is friendly. Our room was a large two room suite on the 7th floor overlooking 3rd Avenue, providing hours of entertainment during a huge snowstorm. The subway was close, but we walked to most tourist destinations, even during the snow. There are several decent restarants nearby. We especially enjoyed the bagels at Ess-a-bagel every morning. Don't expect fancy decor or the amenities of a large hotel, but do expect room to stretch out, kitchen facilities, a pleasant staff, and a decent rate.  
<Date>Mar 22, 2004
